ayahs.text:
This verse begins with a severe warning: "Woe to every slanderer and backbiter." The terms 'humazah' and 'lumazah' are closely related in meaning, both referring to those who constantly find fault with others and engage in mockery and ridicule. According to some linguists, 'humazah' refers to one who mocks and taunts people to their faces, while 'lumazah' refers to one who backbites and finds faults behind people's backs, though other linguists have given the reverse meanings.

These terms encompass all those who engage in tale-bearing, create division and discord among friends, and constantly seek to find flaws in innocent and blameless people. This behavior represents a fundamental character defect that stems from arrogance, jealousy, and a lack of spiritual refinement. Such individuals spend their time and energy in destructive criticism rather than constructive engagement with society.

This verse describes the materialistic obsession of such people: "Who gathers wealth and counts it repeatedly." The verse portrays someone who has wasted their entire life and all their struggles in accumulating money and keeping detailed accounts of it. Such a person derives pleasure from constantly calculating and recalculating their wealth, thinking about how much their accounts have increased this month compared to the previous one.

This obsession with wealth accumulation becomes the defining characteristic of their existence. They spend their time monitoring percentage increases in their assets and comparing this year's wealth to last year's holdings. This constant counting and recounting reveals an unhealthy attachment to material possessions that consumes their thoughts and energy, leaving little room for spiritual or moral development.

This verse reveals the delusion behind such behavior: "He thinks that his wealth will make him immortal." The wealthy person believes that their riches have made them eternally lasting. Through their wealth, they desire to leave such marks and traces in the world that their name will remain forever in history. This same human desire has compelled people to create wonders like the Egyptian pyramids.

The famous English poem 'The Pyramids' reflects this very human psychology in these words: 'Calm and self-possessed, Still and resolute, Pyramids echo into eternity, They defined cry of man's will To strive conquer the storms of time.' This verse exposes the fundamental error in thinking that material wealth can provide any form of permanence or protection against the ultimate reality of death and divine judgment.

This verse delivers a firm rejection of such delusions: "By no means! He will surely be thrown into Al-Hutamah." The word 'Hutamah' comes from the root 'hatama,' meaning that which breaks, crushes, grinds, and reduces everything to fragments and pieces. This is the name of a specific level of Hell whose fire will be so intense that whatever is thrown into it will be instantly ground to pieces.

The definitive tone of this verse, beginning with 'kalla' (by no means), completely rejects the false notion that wealth can provide any protection or immortality. Instead of the imagined security and permanence, the reality is a terrible punishment in this crushing fire that will completely destroy and pulverize everything that enters it.

This verse poses a rhetorical question to emphasize the severity of the punishment: "And what will make you know what Al-Hutamah is?" This questioning technique is used throughout the Quran to draw attention to the magnitude and incomprehensible nature of divine punishment. The human mind cannot fully grasp the reality and intensity of this particular form of punishment.

The question serves to heighten the sense of awe and fear regarding this punishment, preparing the reader for the description that follows. It suggests that Al-Hutamah is beyond ordinary human experience and understanding, representing a level of divine justice that transcends worldly comprehension.

This verse provides the answer to the previous question: "It is Allah's kindled fire." This fire is specifically attributed to Allah, indicating its divine origin and intensity. Unlike ordinary fire, this is a supernatural flame that has been ignited by divine command and possesses qualities far beyond any earthly fire that humans might know or experience.

The description of this fire as being 'kindled' or 'lit' by Allah emphasizes that it is not a natural phenomenon but a deliberate instrument of divine justice. This divine fire represents the ultimate consequence for those who have spent their lives in spiritual darkness, mocking others and being obsessed with material accumulation while neglecting their spiritual duties and moral obligations.

This verse describes a unique characteristic of this divine fire: "Which mounts directed at the hearts." The heat and intensity of this fire will affect the heart more than the skin, reaching deep into the core of a person's being. This is not merely physical torment but spiritual and emotional anguish that strikes at the very center of human consciousness and feeling.

Now that humans have discovered various types of fire and heat, including infrared rays and ultraviolet rays, it has become easier to understand this characteristic of Al-Hutamah. Some have suggested that Al-Hutamah might be some form of atomic heat, noting that the heat emanating from atoms is not direct fire but penetrates through human existence, affecting the inner being rather than just the surface.

This verse describes the inescapable nature of this punishment: "Indeed, it will be closed over them." The fire will be sealed shut over the inhabitants, ensuring that all of its heat affects them completely and they experience maximum suffering. There will be no escape, no relief, and no respite from this punishment.

The closing or sealing of the fire creates a concentrated environment where the full intensity of the punishment is focused on those within. This represents the complete and total nature of divine justice, where there are no loopholes or means of avoiding the consequences of one's actions.

This final verse completes the description of the punishment: "In columns extended." The fire is structured in extended columns or pillars, creating a vast and organized system of punishment. This architectural description suggests a permanent and well-established structure, not a temporary or haphazard arrangement.

The mention of extended columns implies both the magnitude and the systematic nature of this divine punishment. Just as the wealthy person organized and systematically counted their wealth in worldly life, their punishment in the afterlife is also organized and systematic, but in a way that brings suffering rather than satisfaction. This serves as a powerful reminder that divine justice is thorough, organized, and inescapable.
